Introduction

Caustic ingestion involves the accidental or intentional swallowing of corrosive substances.  These acidic or alkaline chemicals can rapidly cause significant tissue damage when introduced into the digestive tract.  Symptoms of caustic ingestion may include dysphagia, drooling, hoarseness, chest pain, and respiratory distress.  Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the test of choice to assess the extent of mucosal injury and determine management.

Risk factors



  • Age:
    • In young children, ingestions are most often accidental and the amount consumed is typically small.
    • In teens and adults, ingestions are usually intentional and involve a large quantity of caustic material.
  • Psychiatric conditions (eg, suicidal ideation, depression)
  • Access to corrosive chemicals:
    • Alkaline chemicals include oven cleaner, dishwasher detergents, or laundry pods.
    • Acidic chemicals include toilet cleaners or battery fluid (eg, button batteries).
  • Access to highly concentrated substances:  These are more likely to cause severe injury (household bleach, a commonly ingested substance, is typically not alkaline enough to cause significant caustic injury when consumed)

Pathogenesis



Caustic substances cause injury through direct chemical reactions with tissues.  Acidic and alkaline compounds act by different mechanisms:

Acids:  pH <7



  • Acids may cause coagulation necrosis; contact with mucosa results in thrombosis of superficial vessels and formation of a protective eschar at the site.  The eschar may prevent deeper penetration of the acid and limit further necrosis.
  • Acids are typically ingested in smaller amounts due to unpleasant taste and immediate throat pain upon swallowing.
  • Patients often have upper airway (eg, epiglottis) injury secondary to choking or gagging on the acidic chemical.
  • Acids are more likely to cause gastric injury; damage can be extensive due to acid-induced antral spasm, which delays stomach emptying and prolongs acid contact with the stomach wall.  Perforation with peritonitis may occur.

Alkalis:  pH >7



  • Alkalis may cause liquefaction necrosis, which occurs when cell lysis releases digestive enzymes that rapidly penetrate through multiple tissue layers, leading to severe tissue destruction within seconds.
  • Alkalis are more commonly ingested than acids and in larger amounts.
  • Deep, extensive injuries most often occur in the esophagus rather than the stomach (because the stomach acid provides partial neutralization of the alkali).
  • Full-thickness necrosis of the esophagus can lead to perforation, resulting in mediastinitis.

Clinical presentation



Mucosal injury results from direct contact with the caustic substance (rather than from systemic absorption); therefore, onset of symptoms typically occurs rapidly.  Clinical findings may include:



  • Oropharyngeal, chest, or abdominal pain
  • Oral erythema and ulcerations
  • Dysphagia, odynophagia
  • Hypersalivation/drooling (due to difficulty managing oral secretions)
  • Vomiting, occasional hematemesis


Aspiration of alkalis or acids can cause injury to the epiglottis, larynx, trachea, and bronchi.  These injuries present with the following symptoms:



  • Hoarseness
  • Stridor
  • Tachypnea
  • Hypoxemia
  • Respiratory failure/airway compromise


Transmural necrosis can lead to perforation of either the esophagus or stomach, resulting in:



  • Mediastinitis (esophagus):  severe chest pain, fever, subcutaneous air (ie, crepitus), pleural effusion
  • Peritonitis (lower esophagus or stomach):  abdominal pain, rebound, guarding, rigidity

 Diagnosis



A caustic ingestion is often suspected based on a history of swallowing a corrosive chemical.  The initial evaluation seeks to determine the identity and quantity/concentration of substance(s) consumed as well as the time and reason ingestion occurred.  However, the history may be unclear or unavailable; therefore, a high index of suspicion is necessary when evaluating patients with symptoms such as drooling, dysphagia, hoarseness, and chest pain.



A caustic injury is confirmed by direct visualization of injured esophageal/gastric tissue using esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD).  EGD should be performed within the first 24 hours in symptomatic patients or patients with large and/or intentional ingestions in order to assess the extent of injury and guide management.



If mediastinitis or peritonitis is suspected, a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen can be used to gauge the severity of esophageal/gastric wall necrosis and assess for perforation (an indication for immediate surgery).  A CT scan is particularly useful in this case because EGD is contraindicated if a perforation is identified.

Differential diagnosis



  • Foreign body ingestion:  This can cause drooling, dysphagia and chest pain, but there is typically a history of swallowing a foreign body prior to symptom onset.  Imaging (eg, x-ray of the chest) can often identify the presence of a foreign object in the gastrointestinal tract. 
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):  Symptoms (including burning chest pain and sometimes dysphagia) are typically chronic and lack the rapid onset of an acute caustic ingestion.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing is not required to diagnose a caustic ingestion injury but may be obtained during the general assessment or in preparation for surgery (eg, perforation repair).



  • Complete blood count:  may reveal inflammatory leukocytosis or anemia (if severe hematemesis)
  • Complete metabolic panel:  may assess for renal dysfunction and abnormal electrolytes that may impact surgical planning
  • Coagulation profile:  may determine any coagulopathy prior to intervention
  • Drug panel:  may determine any coingestants (if intentional ingestion)

Imaging



The following imaging tests may be useful when evaluating a patient with a caustic ingestion:



  • X-ray of chest and/or abdomen:  may detect free air (indicating perforation), but does not provide details about location or severity of tissue injury
  • CT scan of the chest and abdomen with contrast:  provides a reliable, rapid, noninvasive assessment of the extent and depth of injury.  It is particularly useful to identify patients with transmural necrosis and perforation who require immediate surgery.

Management



The first step in managing caustic ingestions is to assess airway, breathing, and circulation.



  • Intubate if there is evidence of respiratory distress (eg, tachypnea, stridor, hypoxemia).
  • Administer intravenous fluids for hemodynamic support.
  • Remove any contaminated clothing to avoid continued exposure to caustic material.


Unstable patients with clinical signs of mediastinitis or peritonitis and evidence of perforation on CT scan require:



  • Immediate surgical intervention (eg, laparotomy)
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • Admission to intensive care unit


Patients who lack signs of perforation but are symptomatic (eg, dysphagia, drooling) or have ingested a highly concentrated or large volume of corrosive substance should be evaluated with an EGD, the diagnostic study of choice to evaluate and grade the extent of tissue injury.  EGD should be performed within 24 hours of ingestion.



  • Patients with low-grade tissue injury (eg, mucosal hyperemia) may be discharged with close outpatient follow-up, pain control, and a liquid diet for 24-48 hours.
  • Patients with severe injuries (eg, deep ulcerations) require â‰¥7 days of inpatient monitoring for complications (eg, perforation).  If unable to tolerate oral intake after 48 hours, enteral feeding may be necessary.


Patients who are asymptomatic after a small, accidental ingestion do not necessarily need an EGD and may be discharged (with close follow-up) at the discretion of the examining provider.



The following are important reminders when managing any caustic ingestion:



  • Do not induce vomiting, which would reexpose the esophagus to the caustic agent and potentially cause further injury.
  • Do not administer neutralizing agents.  Because esophageal damage occurs instantaneously, neutralizing agents are not effective.  In addition, acid-base reactions are exothermic and could cause further injury.
  • Do not allow patient to consume anything by mouth until severity of injury and management plan have been established.

Prognosis



Mild-to-moderate caustic injuries typically have a good prognosis with full recovery.  Severe caustic injuries have a higher risk for complications, which include:



  • Early:  perforation, mediastinitis, peritonitis, bleeding
  • Late:  esophageal strictures (most common), tracheoesophageal fistulas, or squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.  A swallow study is used to diagnose esophageal strictures that can occur weeks to months after the initial exposure.  Therefore, patients with caustic ingestion should have routine screening for esophageal cancer up to 15-20 years after ingestion.

Summary
